skill.name: uniprot-database
skill.description: Direct REST API access to UniProt. Protein searches, FASTA retrieval, ID mapping, Swiss-Prot/TrEMBL. For Python workflows with multiple databases, prefer bioservices (unified interface to 40+ services). Use this for direct HTTP/REST work or UniProt-specific control.
skill.summary: Direct REST API access to UniProt. Protein searches, FASTA retrieval, ID mapping, Swiss-Prot/TrEMBL....
skill.author: K-Dense-AI

security_audit.summary: This skill makes HTTP requests only to the official UniProt REST API (https://rest.uniprot.org). No filesystem access, no environment variable reads, no command execution. Pure data retrieval tool for protein information.

content.value_statement: Query UniProt for protein sequences, functional annotations, and cross-references. Retrieve FASTA sequences, map identifiers between databases, and access Swiss-Prot and TrEMBL entries through a REST API.
actual_capabilities: Search proteins by name, gene, accession, organism, or GO term
Retrieve protein sequences in FASTA, JSON, TSV, XML, or other formats
Map protein identifiers between UniProt and external databases
Stream large result sets for batch downloads
Access Swiss-Prot reviewed and TrEMBL unreviewed entries
Get protein annotations including GO terms, domains, and functions
limitations: API rate limits apply to large batch requests
Maximum 100,000 IDs per ID mapping job
Results stored for 7 days after ID mapping jobs
No local data caching or offline access

use_cases.title: Protein sequence retrieval
use_cases.description: Search and download protein sequences for genes of interest in FASTA format for downstream analysis

use_cases.title: Cross-reference databases
use_cases.description: Map UniProt accessions to PDB structures, Ensembl IDs, or RefSeq for integrated analysis workflows

use_cases.title: Explore protein annotations
use_cases.description: Query protein function, GO terms, and domain information for teaching or literature review

prompt_templates.title: Basic protein search
prompt_templates.prompt: Search UniProt for human insulin proteins using the query: insulin AND organism_id:9606 AND reviewed:true

prompt_templates.title: Get sequence data
prompt_templates.prompt: Get the FASTA sequence for UniProt accession P01308

prompt_templates.title: Map identifiers
prompt_templates.prompt: Map these UniProt accessions to PDB IDs: P01308 and P04637

prompt_templates.title: Batch search
prompt_templates.prompt: Stream all reviewed human kinase proteins in FASTA format

output_examples.input: Search UniProt for human hemoglobin proteins
output: Sequences range from 141 to 147 amino acids

best_practices: Use reviewed:true filter to get manually curated Swiss-Prot entries for high-quality data
Specify only the fields you need to reduce bandwidth and improve response times
Implement rate limiting for large batch operations to respect API resources
Cache frequently accessed protein data locally to minimize repeated API calls
anti_patterns: Requesting all fields for simple lookups increases response size and processing time
Ignoring the reviewed flag mixes high-quality curated entries with computational predictions
Making synchronous calls for thousands of IDs without batching can timeout or hit rate limits
Using outdated accession numbers without checking for deprecated entries

faq.question: Which UniProt entry types are available?
faq.answer: Swiss-Prot (reviewed, manually curated) and TrEMBL (unreviewed, computationally predicted). Use reviewed:true to filter.

faq.question: What is the maximum query size?
faq.answer: The search endpoint returns up to 500 results per request with pagination. Use the stream endpoint for large datasets.

faq.question: Can I use this with Python scripts?
faq.answer: Yes, the skill provides a Python client (scripts/uniprot_client.py) with functions for all major operations.

faq.question: Is my query data stored or shared?
faq.answer: No. This skill only retrieves data from UniProt. Your queries are not stored or transmitted elsewhere.

faq.question: Why did my ID mapping job fail?
faq.answer: Check that your IDs exist and the source and target databases are valid. Failed IDs are returned in the results.

faq.question: How does this differ from bioservices?
faq.answer: This skill provides direct UniProt REST access. Use bioservices for unified access to 40+ bioinformatics databases.
